direction.raw_text: Darkness. The sound of battle cries and the clang of metal upon metal. The forest lights up with huge sparks flying from sword and ax as armored knights hack and swing at each other. Mounted knights collide head-on at full gallop, their armor made incandescent in the clash. Sparks eddy in their wakes and float to the ground. The forest catches fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on the flames. Out of the sounds of ancient battle grows music, heroic and barbaric, shot through with melancholy. Two crazed eyes reflect the fire. The eyes belong to a man without age, at once ancient and boyish, female and male; his eyes are pained from the burden of too much knowledge. So close is he to the flames that a lock of his wild hair sizzles alight. He slaps at the fire as if it were an annoying insect. He wears a cloak of black trimmed with silver. It is Merlin. The wizard weaves a path through the burning forest, dodging the combatants, searching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The forest around him weeps softly with the sounds that follow slaughter. Patches of undergrowth are smoldering. Small flames lick bark and branches. Smoke floats through the trees and hovers over the bodies of the dying and the dead. A huge knight reins up beside Merlin on a lathered horse. His armor is blood spattered. He is weary from battle. He looks down at Merlin, his countenance fierce. The blade of his sword glows with an unnatural aura.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Lord Uther! Lord Uther!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's done. A truce. We meet at the river.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (disgusted) Talk. Lovers murmuring to each other...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Waiting on one bank of a small river that flows through the forest is a warlord, the Duke of Cornwall. He is flanked by his armored warriors. Lot of Lowthean prominent among them. They are battle-weary and bloodied, but they look ready to fight. Behind them is an army of lesser knights. To the opposite bank come Uther and Merlin, a much smaller force of knights, including Uryens, Lord of Gore, surrounding them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uther and the Duke of Cornwall glare at each other in silence across the river. Uther strains forward, burning with anger; but Merlin restrains him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uther unsheathes his mighty sword, and brandishes it in the air high over his head. The blade hums disquietingly and leaves a lingering electric hue upon the air. The marvel instills dread in all present.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Duke of Cornwall looks around nervously as some of his knights fall to their knees in awe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merlin urges Uther hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The two knights glare at each other, rage contending with anger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The enemies lock eyes and Merlin watches anxiously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All men from both sides break out in wild cheers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Merlin is nowhere in sight.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I spit on your truce, Uther. If you want peace, throw down your swords.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I should butcher all and every one of them. Merlin, what is this wagging of tongues?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just show the sword.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (waxing eloquent) Behold the sword of power, Excalibur. Before Uther, it belonged to Lud, before Lud, to Beowulf, before Beowulf to Baldur the Good, before Baldur to Thor himself and that was when the world was young and there were more than seven colors in the rainbow. (and in an aside to Uther) Speak the words.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bellowing) One land, one king! That is my peace!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lord Uther, if I yield to the sword of power, what will you yield?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Me, yield!?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a whisper) He has given. Now you must.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The land from here to the sea is yours if you will enforce the King's will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Done!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My Lord King Uther, let us feast together. To my castle. Lord Merlin, you must join -
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Drums and wailing flutes fill the banquet hall with a lusty rhythm. Armored warriors watch a lone woman dancing. She is very beautiful, both sensuous and innocent. Uther sits at the long table beside the Duke of Cornwall with the barons and dukes of the land, and the lesser knights. The table is stained with wine and littered with bones and half-eaten fruit. Uther's eyes burn with lust as he watches the dancer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Duke rises and goes to his wife, be-striding the center of the hall and Igrayne weaves circles of dance around him. He gloats with pride. The words escape his lips:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lot spins to face him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uther is not one for politics, and Lot's words sail past him. The King lusts for Igrayne. A bell is struck not far away. The music ceases and the hall falls silent. The great door creaks open, revealing the dawn light, and a monk steps into the hall and waits by it. Muffled by corridors of stone, a choir of monks can now be heard singing the high, ecstatic harmonies of the Te Deum. Those who have fallen asleep at the table are roused, those drunk, helped up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I would wish you such a wife, Lord Uther, as my Igrayne. So innocent, but in bed, a furnace...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I must have her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What? You're mad! What about the alliance?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (oblivious) I must have her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And risk all you've won? This castle commands the sea gate to the kingdom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The monk leads the party down the hallway of the castle. Thin shafts of dawnlight filter through archers' slits in the thick walls onto stone floors. Otherwise, it is dark. Each person, lady and knight, proceeds alone, head bent, some crossing themselves. Uther is among them. He stops in a dark alcove, breathing heavily, waiting. As the lovely Igrayne drifts past him, he pulls her out of sight of the others. In a shaft of pale light Uther clasps Igrayne to his breastplate, his iron arm wrapped around her frail body. So violent is his embrace that she cannot breathe, her mouth is wide with fear, and her feet do not touch the ground; an impaled butterfly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His face is close to hers, looking as though he would devour her tender whiteness with his kiss. She doesn't answer; she can't. Even Uther understands this and lets her go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her gown and her fragile skin torn on the spikes of his armor, Igrayne backs away and joins the procession. Uther trembles with unreleased passion.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You will be mine. Wife and queen, bed and crown.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a fierce whisper) I want no other crown and no other bed than those I have.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Igrayne enters the candlelit chapel from which issues the chant, calling the castle to worship. She rushes to her husband's side, kneeling next to him and whispering. The Duke of Cornwall looks back at Uther, hatred in his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uther is in a towering rage. Sword drawn, he stalks among the biers of fallen knights. Squires and clerics keep a healthy distance. The sky is lowering, pregnant with rolling thunder. Beyond his encampment, high on a cliff rising out of the sea stands the impregnable Tintagel Castle, seat of the Duke of Cornwall, now under siege.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just then a knight rides up and dismounts. It is Ulfius, a lieutenant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But he cannot finish. He is taken aback by the sudden appearance of a hideous hag who approaches, rattling a beggar's pan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The figure straightens, the filthy rags become a flowing cape, and the hair is swept back by the wind, andoit is Merlin, laughing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ulfius edges away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Duke of Cornwall under siege. All this for lust. Selfish lust. Uther grabs Merlin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merlin frowns pensively, his gaze searching strange distances and wandering; then focusing, blazing straight at Uther.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uther kneels and draws his sword and holds it up by the blade, a cross.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merlin looks down sorrowfully at the kneeling King.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (bellowing in all directions) Merlin! Where are you!?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you found him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What a hurry you were in this morning, good sir. You forgot to give this old woman a coin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I saw you half a day's gallop from here. I asked you if you had seen Merlin. I returned here straight away. How did -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: heard. I have come. I am also Merlin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have walked my way since the beginning of time. Sometimes I give, sometimes I take. It is mine to know which, and when.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (exploding) Dumb riddles, Merlin. I am your King.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know the storm inside you, and what it has wrought. The alliance I forged is wrecked.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For Igrayne. One night with her. Do it. Use the magic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You will swear by your true kingship to grant me what I wish. Then you shall have it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I swear it. By Excalibur and the holy--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: --What issues from your lust will be mine. Swear it again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I swear it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Duke of Cornwall watches a force of armored knights riding forth from Uther's war camp, with banners flying. It passes beneath the castle and on toward a distant cliff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His eyes are as cold and as pale as ice.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to a lieutenant) It's Uther and all his best knights. He leaves behind little more than fledglings to guard his camp.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Uther and his knights, and Merlin on a mule, ride to the high promontory and dismount. Here, overlooking the sea, is a circle of ancient stones, carved with strange runes and hieroglyphics, and as the wind moves through them it moans and sighs. The knights watch as Merlin and Uther, leading his horse, walk toward the stones. Merlin strides into the circle, turning to look at Uther, who hesitates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uther starts to make the sign of the cross, but Merlin halts him with a gesture. Uther's hand drops, and he enters the circle with his horse. Merlin and Uther look out across the sea, to Tintagel Castle high upon the cliff. Merlin solemnly raises his arms toward that distant castle, and chants in an ancient language, the sounds of which he marries to the roaring and whining of the wind. The wind becomes stronger, and Merlin's incantations become more intense, and the wind in turn becomes wilder still. Until Merlin is charged with a fierce, nonhuman power, as the wind buffets his slight frame. And then, for all to understand:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Come.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hold the balance of all things in my summoning. Arise mists. Come fog.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: From the horizon a front of fog advances toward the castle to envelop it, and continues across the gulf to the circle of stones.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The portal opens and a small force of armored men, led by the Duke of Cornwall, exits. A fog is thickening all around them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The advancing front envelops Merlin and Uther, eddying around the stones.  All else is obliterated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The King does.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uther spurs straight for the edge of the cliff, then reins in his horse abruptly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merlin rages, crazed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gives the horse a stinging blow with his staff. The horse and Uther charge forward into a gallop and stepping off where the hidden edge of the cliff would be, hoofbeats ceasing and the horse dropping for the blink of an eye, they gallop across the fog.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mount your horse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ride straight to the castle, across the sea of fog.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But the cliff, the sea...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ride across! Across the bridges of desire. Your lust will hold you up. For I have just woven it into the fabric of the world. This is magic - making solid what is in the mind, and unsolid, that which is already solid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Galloping on no visible terrain, Uther and his horse advance through the restless fog, and as they recede rider and animal become a wavering, changeable form within the cloud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Horse and rider pull up at the gate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If it was not for the electric blue hue burning in the eyes of the man entering the castle, the same magic hue that Excalibur left upon the air when wielded, the resemblance to the Duke if Cornwall would be perfect. After a moment the portal opens.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (calling) Wake up in there. It is I.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He passes into an inner court, the portal closing behind. Armed men emerge cautiously. Thinking that it is their Duke they help him dismount.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An inner gate opens and the 'Duke' goes through it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Have the horse ready. I ride out before sunrise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The real Duke and his men ride through the fogbound camp, cutting the ropes of the tents, stabbing the men trapped beneath the canvas. When a frightened crow flies squawking into the face of the Duke's horse, which rears. He is unhorsed and falls, and impales himself on a tent stake. Dying, the true Lord of Tintagel Castle rises and staggers forward, blood pumping from him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A little girl of four awakens from a nightmare, a small lone figure in her canopied bed. Her eyes are ice, like her father's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Igrayne is soon at her side, lifting the child from the bed, holding her tight.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Papa... Papa...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My father is dead...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The 'Duke' enters. The room is empty, but the door to Morgana's room is open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The 'Duke' stands in the doorway. Igrayne herself is surprised.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Igrayne kisses Morgana, tucks her in and returns to her own room, closing the door. The child doesn't know whether to believe the truth of the dream or the waking truth.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Look, here is your father. It was just a dream, little one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come Igrayne.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: In full armor, the 'Duke' bears down on the naked Igrayne on her marriage bed. She stares at him, wondering. But his eyes are closed, and finally he carries her in his wild passion, her white limbs tangling around the lustre of his armor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Merlin is jolted awake from deep within himself, coming out of a trance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He lifts himself up on his staff. He stands in the midst of the ancient stones, bristling with excitement. Uther's mighty knights are asleep, a deep unnatural sleep, huddled together and surrounded by their horses. And then Merlin swoons, collapsing to the ground.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It is done. The future has found root in the present.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: His lieutenants deposit the Duke of Cornwall's bloodless body upon the long table. His eyes are wide open, icy and cunning even in death. The ladies of the castle support and comfort the grief-stricken Igrayne as she approaches the body of her husband. Morgana hangs onto her mother's gown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pale with grief, Igrayne stares at her dead husband in silence. Then her hand drifts to her stomach. When she talks again, undone and resolved, it is to all and herself:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Morgana shows no distress. She runs her baby hands across her father's face and closes his eyes. The intensity that was frozen in them is now added to her own pale and cunning eyes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: When did it happen? Where?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In the camp of Uther, my lady, just after nightfall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It can't be. He came to me, to his bed, last night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was his spirit, yearning for you in his hour of death, that visited you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His spirit?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tintagel Castle falls to Uther. But what shall become of me, and the child I bear?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Merlin has been propped up against one of the stones. He is in a deep trance and Uther is attempting to shake him awake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merlin's eyes open but he sees nothing, and only a puzzling squeal issues from him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I want her, Merlin. I cannot be without her. Tintagel is mine. Can I take her now? Tell me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . IGRAYNE'S BEDCHAMBER, TINTAGEL CASTLE- EVENING Morgana watches from a corner. The ladies of the castle surround Igrayne who is giving birth. Noisy crows alight on the windowsill. Only Morgana notices.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uther strides to Igrayne's bedchamber, his warrior knights following. He is dirty and his iron dress is blood-spattered.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (bellowing) Three horses died under me, so hard did I spur them here. Is it born? Is it alive?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: At his approach and entrance the ladies shrink back, and Morgana edges closer to her mother, and seats herself on the bed beside her. Ingrain holds her newborn baby in her arms, the blood of birth still wet upon it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The ladies slip past him to the door, and he goes up to Igrayne.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terrified of him, Igrayne faces him the best she can.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uther waves away her words but does sit down on the bed, exhausted. He notices Morgana, who stares at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Igrayne draws the child to her and kisses her cheek.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The child leaves silently, hatred in her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He grasps the newborn baby with his iron hand, and pulls it to himself. He looks upon it with wonder, with a gentleness that is unexpected.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He can't bring himself to say his name. She hesitates on the edge of tears, worried for the infant lying in its iron cradle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uther draws a dagger. He lifts it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But he uses it before Igrayne can move. He severs the leather thongs that bind the iron breastplate to his chest. He casts it to the floor. His chest is smooth and milk-white in striking contrast to his creased, weathered face. And beaming, he holds the baby to it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Igrayne's hatred for the man is at the very edge of becoming love. The baby starts to cry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And his free hand opens her shift, and he holds a swollen breast in his gloved hand, squeezing gently. Milk bubbles from it and he thrusts the baby's mouth onto it. Igrayne weeps and Uther watches proudly as the baby suckles. Merlin advances from the window, his cape the same iridescent green-black as the feathers of the crows that were perched by the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uther avoids looking at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uther is shaken to his roots. Igrayne watches, trying to understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Igrayne suddenly understands. She glares at Uther.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uther is caught, and turns to Merlin who is harsh and unswaying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uther wrenches the baby from it's mother's breast and hands him to Merlin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With the bawling baby under his cape, Merlin exits. Igrayne pulls herself out of the bed, weak, her legs giving under her. She starts after Merlin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uther stops her with his bulk and she claws savagely at his chest to get past him. He weeps as he folds his arms around her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is it, lady?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A boy, sir. Rest yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Send the girl away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She is just a child -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (whispering) Go now. Come back later.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She watches me with her father's eyes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Igrayne, is he mine, or -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The night he died, a man loved me with great fierceness. He looked like my husband, spoke like, smelled like, felt like my own husband. But it was not he, for he was already dead. It wasn't his spirit, for this child, who was conceived that night, is flesh and blood. I know nothing more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Through him, I will learn to love them, for I am tired of battle. I will stay by his side and (looking shyly at Igrayne) his mother's...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here. It's hungry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Merlin! Out of the sick sleep at last.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Doing what I did for you, it wasn't easy, you know. It takes it's toll. It took nine moons to get back my strength.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now you must pay me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The child is mine, Uther. I have come for him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The oath. You didn't say--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You didn't ask!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uther, is it true? Don't let him take the child.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I swore an oath, Igrayne. I made a pact with Merlin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was you? You came to me that night. You are the father.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not for you, Uther, hearth and home, wife and child.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To kill and be king, is that all?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe not even that, Uther. I thought once that you were the one to unite the land under one sword. But it'll take another, a greater king...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You strike me with words as hard as steel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They are not weapons, my friend, but truths. You betrayed the Duke, stole his wife and took his castle, now no one trusts you. Lot, Uryens, your allies will turn against you. Give me the child, Uther, I will protect him. Go back to your war tent.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in torment) By the oath, take the devil child. Take him!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ?... Why must he have the baby?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Merlin walks through the castle, the baby crying in his arms, the knights and ladies step back, afraid to intervene in royal matters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Merlin comes across the empty banquet hall, cooing to the baby, strangely pacifying him. Morgana steps out of the shadows in his path, and Merlin stops at the sight of the little girl, her pale eyes glaring at him. She speaks haltingly and clearly while far-off Igrayne cries out her distress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Staring at her, Merlin shudders and without answering he continues away, faster now, and into an unlit passageway, disappearing from sight a bit sooner than an ordinary mortal would have.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Merlin, are you now the father, and the mother, of the baby?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The forest is dark and shiny with rain. An unseen battle rages. The first combatant in sight is Uther, who swings the mighty Excalibur, cutting an attacker in half at the waist. Uther and a small force of knights, Ulfius among them, are retreating through the slippery wet forest, completely outnumbered. Lord Lot of Lowthean and Lord Uryens of Gore are the leaders of the attack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ulfius and his men stand their ground so the King may escape the onslaught. They are hacked down. Uther flees alone, severing the limbs of any man and tree that stands in his way.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to his men) The King's sword. I must have it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Uther has gained on his pursuers. He comes to a small clearing where the spine of a buried boulder rises through the forest floor. He stops upon it, breathing hard, dripping blood. He rages aloud, but his throat is raw and cracked and only a whisper comes out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hears his pursuers closing in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He holds it by the hilt with both hands, the blade pointing to the ground of stone. He flexes his knees. He lifts up his hands above his head. And with all the strength that rage and pain can muster, and more, he drives the blade of Excalibur into the stone, nearly to the hilt. His mouth widens in an awful silent scream, and then the foam of saliva pink with blood issues from deep within him, so violent was his effort. As the sword cuts into the rock, the earth shudders.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Merlin, where are you? To weave a mist, to hide us...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No one shall have the sword. No one shall wield Excalibur but me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The forest quakes. The knights searching for Uther halt in fear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And far away, a caped figure is crossing a field toward a wood, when the earth shakes, stirring animals and birds. The man turns. He is Merlin, the two day-old baby peeking from his cape. Merlin is amazed at the phenomenon, he puts his ear to a rock protruding from the earth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And tears welling, and giggling at the same time, he whisks away into the woods.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Into the spine of the dragon! (and then he is saddened) Uther... I loved you, mighty child.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Uther staggers away, colliding with trees, staggering, crashing to the ground. Until the only life left in him is the coursing of his blood, flowing from his gaping mouth onto the leaves on the forest floor. The enemy knights advance through the trees. They prod at the fallen leviathan, they roll him over to get at his scabbard. Only then do they see the sword in the stone, and they stop, amazed and afraid. Their captains appear. Uryens sees what they are staring at, and races to the sword and attempts to pull it out. He strains with all his might, but it is immovable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He shoves Uryens aside, but he can't loosen the sword either, and he rages with frustration.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Let me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : "Fifteen years passed and the land was without a king."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peasants spill over the crest of a hill. They are fleeing a force of armored knights, their plumed helmets forged in the semblance of predatory animals. The knights thunder past the peasants, trampling the ripening crops. Sir Uryens is their leader, his hard face indifferent to the havoc he leaves in his wake. The peasants watch in mute anger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir Lot leading another group of mounted knights comes galloping into a small hamlet, panicked chickens and pigs scattering at their approach. The farmers run for their lives as the steel men dismount, leading their horses to water and hay, and searching for vittles. A knight spots a woman who stands frozen with fear, and he drags her into the barn as her crying child watches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MOONLIGHT A farmhouse is burning nearby, and three mounted figures make their way along a trail at a walking pace - an old knight in leather and mail, a young knight proud in gleaming new armor; and on a farm horse, a squire with baggage and jousting lance. The old knight, Sir Ector, is troubled by what he sees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just then, ten crazed peasants emerge from the darkness, hurling stones and armed with clubs and pronged sticks. They surround the three riders. Sir Ector wheels around and slices the air with his sword to ward off the ambushers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The peasants edge closer, working up the nerve to rush the horsemen. The sound of thundering hooves cuts through the clamor. A cavalcade of riders, armor gleaming in the moonlight, advances across the fields at a gallop. Immediately the peasants scatter. The old knight is on the verge of tears.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It is a dark hour... everywhere lawlessness and destruction, and no one to lead us out of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen all. I am Sir Ector of Morven and these are my sons. You would wrong me, for I have never stolen from others, or destroyed the fruit of the land.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The people's anger is just. It is sad that for our own safety, we will have to ride to the tournament with these robber knights.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Red with the first light of day, Excalibur rests in the stone as King Uther left it. The field is itched with tents, each flying its heraldic banner. Knights and squires are everywhere, preparing horses and armor for the joust. A burly man in religious robes harangues the crowd, vying for attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Bishop goes among the tents, through the teeming throng, solemnly casting holy water upon man and horse, armor and banner. The knights kneel at the Bishop's transit, but ceremony does not lift the air of grimness that lies over the event.
direction.name: direction

location: SITE OF THE SWORD IN THE STONE
result.heading: EXT.

dialogue.raw_text: This is Easter day, when Christ rose again. Who will find strength in victory of arms? Who will draw the sword?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Their armor ablaze with sunlight, two mounted knights thunder toward each other at full gallop, lowering their long jousting lances. As they meet, the lance of each knight is deflected by the shield of the other. A gasp goes through the crowd, and the two knights charge past each other. They wheel around at the end of the jousting ground and go at each other again from the other direction. Again lances strike, and this time one of the men is hit in the chest and violently unhorsed. The crowd cheers.
direction.name: direction

location: JOUSTING GROUND, SWORD IN THE STONE
result.heading: EXT.

direction.raw_text: The victor, Leondegrance, rides up to the stone and dismounts. Each great knight with his coterie of lesser knights comes to watch. A charge of expectation is in the air, although most knights are glowering with envy. Leondegrance of Camelyarde ascends to the sword, grabs it by the hilt, and begins to tug with all his might. Excalibur is immovable. The moment of tension passes. Leondegrance staggers toward his waiting squires, who lead him away. All the others return to the battle sport.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At the edge of the jousting ground Sir Ector's son Sir Kay is getting ready for a bout. His brother Arthur is buckling the new armor while his father fusses about him, making small adjustments when he notices that Kay's scabbard is empty. He turns to Arthur and grab's him by the ear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The fifteen year-old boy blushes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boy dashes off as Sir Ector shakes his head, not without affection beneath the sternness.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Arthur, where is Kay's sword? A good squire doesn't forget his knight's sword.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I left it in the tent, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well hurry then, and get it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Arthur runs in search of their tent. He finds it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He enters. The saddle trunk has been emptied on the floor, equipment is scattered all over. Arthur is shocked, nonetheless he rummages madly. Finally he stops, on the verge of tears.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's been stolen....
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He comes out, utterly defeated, and frantic. He stops by two knights who are arguing angrily; and one of them has left his sword in the grass. Arthur looks at it. He is tempted to steal it, but he can't. Head down, he wanders off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir Ector and Sir Kay are waiting.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Father, I'll go and see what's keeping him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Arthur stops at the edge of the dark forest, totally dejected, when he sees the sword in the stone. He walks up to it, his face lighting up, brimming with innocence. He is alone, as everyone has returned to the jousting ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smiles, forgetting his troubles, a boy again living in a fairy tale. He grasps the sword by the hilt and it comes away easily from its stone lock. Not expecting it to, he nearly falls. He stares at it, terribly excited and surprised: he tucks it under his arm and rushes back.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: If only Kay could have it...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He bumps into Kay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kay takes it. He cannot believe what he's holding in his hands. He starts to talk but he is so agitated he can only stutter.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (breathless) Your sword was stolen, Kay, but here is Excalibur. Is it too late? I hurried--
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kay, with Arthur in tow, rushes to Sir Ector and shows him the sword; he trembles with excitement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir Ector is dumbstruck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ector looks at his son amazed, wanting to believe but not able to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With Excalibur in hand Ector of Morven heads for the stone, Kay following, and Arthur too, the boy flushed with excitement but a little worried, not understanding what is happening. The exchange between Sir Ector and Sir Kay has been overheard. Some have seen the sword in Sir Ector's hand. Rumor spreads like wildfire.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Look, Father. Excalibur. Does that mean that I am to be king?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you free the sword, boy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ... did, Father.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We must go to the stone at once.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Sir Ector ascends the stone, from all parts of the jousting ground knights and squires, the Bishop and the clerics, and peasants too, press around. Ector lowers the blade into the tight cleft and Excalibur sinks to its original position.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir Kay grabs the hilt and pulls without conviction, and the sword doesn't give. Eyes downcast, he lets go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts to kneel but Ector pulls him up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arthur is about to grasp the hilt when Uryens and Lot, and other nobles, Leondegrance of Camelyarde, and Sir Caradoc and Sir Turquine among the younger, stride up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uryens, Lot, Leondegrance, Caradoc, Turquine - each in turn grapples with the sword, only to be defeated by its immobility. The crowd around the stone is thickening with common folk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The demand is echoed by peasants and serfs. The great knights remain silent and bitter in their defeat. Sir Ector pushes Arthur to the sword.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boy hesitates shyly, and then takes the hilt of Excalibur and pulls out the sword with a great sweep. The throng is stunned. Silence falls. Some kneel, following the example of Sir Ector and Sir Kay, of the Bishop and Leondegrance. The other nobles stay back, confused, afraid, angered. Arthur stands there, little more than a boy, his cheeks flushed, his soft hair ruffled by the wind, his eyes shining with exultation, awe, and fear. Then, as if gaining confidence from the sword itself, he turns it in arcs above his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The commoners and some of the knights react with roaring enthusiasm. The others draw closer to Uryens and Lot and their supporters, closing ranks around them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir Ector rises, tears streaming down his cheeks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is quite a shock to the boy king, and to the onlookers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merlin's name is on the lips of all those close by.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From out of the forest strides Merlin, dramatic, cape flowing, eyes crazed as ever, laughing at his own entrance. A crow is perched on his shoulder, and it squawks loudly. Annoyed with it, Merlin swooshes it away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merlin interrupts himself when his eyes fall on the boy, who is taking in his performance raptly, half awestruck, half amused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The suspicion and confusion and envy of the lords erupts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The crowd of serfs and peasants cheer wildly, and their long suppressed anger against the nobles comes to the fore. They dare to press up against them, fists hammering on their shields as the chant Arthur King over and over. Dark and scowling, full of rebellion, all the lords except Leondegrance begin to withdraw their iron men surrounding them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Draw it, son!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir, I didn't draw the sword. Arthur gave it to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Arthur ?! (spinning around to face him) How did you get the sword, child?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (frightened) Sir... Kay needed a sword. His was stolen. I saw Excalibur, and... I took it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You freed it, son?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I did, Father. I beg your forgiveness.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Try the sword, Arthur.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stand back, Sir Ector, and take your children.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We will try again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let the boy try the sword.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let the boy try...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go ahead, boy. Don't be afraid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We have our King, thanks be to God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, Father, rise up. I was your son before I became your King... if I am King.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My Lord, you are King, all the more because you are not my son, and I am not your father.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who is, then?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. Merlin brought you to me when you were newly born and charged me to raise you as my own. At first, I did so because I feared Merlin, later because I loved you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who is Merlin?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Speak of the devil!...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am Merlin. Counselor to kings. Wizard and beggar. Prophet and... (he drops it) I have feasted on thunderbolts, I savored my death before I got myself born. I--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whose son am I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are the son of King Uther, and the fair Igrayne... you are King Arthur.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Merlin, we haven't forgotten you. This is more of your trickery.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're trying to foist a boy of dubious birth upon us. You want to shame us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lord Leondegrance, join us against the boy. Surely you can see he is only Merlin's tool.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. I, Leondegrance, Lord of Camelyarde, saw the drawing of Uther's sword, and witnessed no trickery. If a boy has been chosen, a boy shall be king.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Bells toll the good news. People stream by to see the new king and join the celebration.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uryens and Lot, and Caradoc, Turquine, and the other lords have mounted, and are moving out, when from the rear guard a bowman in Lot's service draws upon the unarmored figure of Arthur across the cheering crowd. The bowman lets the arrow fly. It flies over the heads of the crowd, unseen. Except by Merlin at Arthur's side. He extends his arms halfway up, his fists clenched tightly as if drawing urgently on the power within himself. The sound of wings is heard as he flaps his arms. The arrow flies toward Arthur. Arthur sees the arrow coming right at him, when a swooping crow plucks it out of the air. Arthur watches the crow flapping its wings, climbing swiftly, the arrow in its beak, disappearing over the forest. Only he has noticed. When he turns Merlin is no longer at his side; to the puzzlement of all. And Arthur is all of a sudden terribly alone and afraid, as people from all sides clamor for his attention and guidance.
direction.name: direction

location: SITE OF THE SWORD IN THE STONE
result.heading: EXT.

direction.raw_text: Arthur charges through the shadowy forest. He is in armor, but it is only a light tunic of mail. Excalibur is sheathed in a leather scabbard by his side. He is frantic and he calls urgently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His face shines with sweat, the horse is lathered. He dismounts and continues on foot into denser, more tangled undergrowth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A huge eye opens in the foreground of what had appeared to be shadow, bark and tufts of weeds is really Merlin's head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His voice is thin as he is awakening from a deep, exhausted sleep. Arthur finds him lying within the large gnarled roots of a great tree. The boy kneels before Merlin and lifts his hands and kisses them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arthur blurts it out:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arthur helps Merlin up and the wizard stands unsteadily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The forest groans and creaks, alive with murmurs and shrill calls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence. Arthur tries again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just as suddenly, he is his amused, ironic self again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arthur bows his head, confused and almost defeated. Merlin steals a look at him, and puts his arm around the boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He enjoys being cryptic.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...Merlin... Merlin...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Merlin!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You called, sir?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You saved me from the arrow...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a flicker of mischief) But not from your destiny.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's not why you came.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Merlin, help me. I need your help. I don't know how--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (irritated) 'Help me, Help me.' Help me get up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm tired. Doing magic takes its toll, you know. My arms ache terribly... (he makes flying movements with his arms and grimaces) Once--or is it yet to happen--I stood exposed to the Dragon's breath so that a man could lie one night with a woman. It took me ten moons to recover. I'm sure that story would interest you, since... Well, we'll have to talk about it another time. You're too busy now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is whispered in the forest that... (he cups his ear with exaggeration) ...Leondegrance's castle is under siege by Lot and Uryens.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pressing) Yes, yes, I know that. Everybody does. Lord Leondegrance is my only ally among the barons and the great knights. I can't lose him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well there. You don't need me half as much as you think you do. You already know what must not happen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (exasperated) I must find the means to save him, then. I was hoping I could ask you for a little magic help, but if it makes you so tired...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's just that I have no experience, and no men to speak of. How can I-- MERLIN (suddenly fierce) Because you must! You and only you. Have you forgotten that it was you who freed Excalibur?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Besides, it will be a good lesson. (giggling) The best, if it's not the last.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe you'd like to meet the power that gave you the sword?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How? Where?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In the great book.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What book is that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (melodramatic) The book without pages. Open before you, all around us. You can see it in bits and pieces, for if mortal men were to see it whole and all complete in a single glance, why, it would burn him to cinders.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The dragon! There... A deep cleft at the edge of the forest, where far below lava boils with a phosphorescence that lights up a great cloud, billowing upward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merlin points to the sky where roiling clouds appear to be unfurling of immeasurable wings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A terrific wave batters a coastline, spray shooting up, and as the wave recedes it exposes dark rocks and deep crevices.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merlin spins Arthur around, and they are transported into a storm swept forest. Lightning strikes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The trees shine with wetness, as a great wind tosses their crowns, the branches groaning against each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arthur is awestruck.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Coiled in the unfathomed depths, it emerges...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...It unfolds itself in the storm clouds...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...it washes its mane sparkling white in the blackness of seething whirlpools...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...its claws are the forks of lightning... its scales glisten in the bark of trees...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...its voice is heard in the hurricane...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Arthur and Merlin are back in the same spot, having in fact never moved at all, but traveled on the spell of Merlin's words alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arthur's eyes shine with the brilliance of the vision.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...it is so much more than a scaly monster. It is Everything!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And if I am to be King of everything, lord and commoner, beast, leaf and rock, I must use its voice, its claws, its power.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Leondegrance, Lord of Camelyarde, is shocked by what he sees in the distance. His daughter Guenevere, a beautiful girl of sixteen, draws close to him, terrified. With his surviving knights, Leondegrance is making his last stand. The walls have been breached, parts of the castle are burning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A bellowing dragon advances. Its eyes burn, its scales gleam from light shining from within. It snorts fire from its nostrils. Uryens and Lot, Caradoc and Turquine, the great knights in command of the siege of Leondegrance's castle, back away speechless as the monster descends upon their unprepared war camp. All around them, squires and lesser knights flee in panic and confusion. Only a dozen or so remain with their leaders. The group backs up against the swampy moat that surrounds the castle, waiting with swords drawn. The dragon moves closer, and now it becomes apparent that it is nothing more than a force of knights and footmen. Their shields glinting in the moonlight are the dragon's scales, torches its burning eyes. And the snorting flames from its nostrils are only Merlin doing a fire-eater's trick. The dragon form dissolves, and a banner rises bearing the emblem of the Dragon, and under it, Arthur and Ector and Kay lead a charge of twenty knights. In Arthur's hands, Excalibur leaves an electric glow upon the air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Father, it's the boy King.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It is. I will fight my way to his side.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Arthur and his men charge into the enemy ranks. Lot's and Uryens' people are pushed into the moat. Although the water is only waist-deep, the fallen, weighed down by their armor, drown. The horses of the attackers are brought down, Arthur's among them. He pulls out from under it, limping. Bleeding form wounds, cutting, slashing, thrusting, he falls back from the havoc of the charge. A small distance exists now between the foes, a brief respite. Uryens and Lot, exhausted, bleeding, and fierce in their rage:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arthur and his men have been joined by Leondegrance and his knights, few in number.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He rushes alone at the enemy, shouting at the top of his lungs, Excalibur flashing over his head, prepared to die.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: War-wise fighters, grown gray in battle, checkmated by a boy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's Merlin's trickery, nothing more. I won't swear faith to that wizard's brat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's finish this with a show of force. We have no more tricks and no more advantages.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Guenevere watches...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: No... Arthur-- The old knight rushes after the boy, sword drawn, to defend his flank, and the others follow, a battle cry issuing from them that is terrifying in its fierceness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and when she can't watch any longer, she buries her face in her hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arthur fights like a wounded lion at the center of the savage melee of sword and shield, and once again the two sides fall apart. Uryens and Lot are standing in the moat among the bodies of their men, are reduced to eleven knights, all wounded. Arthur is flanked by twenty men at arms, most of them wounded, and trembling now beyond exhaustion with blood lust. Arthur steps forward alone, and addresses his opponents.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arthur turns, searching for Merlin. He spots him watching from a distance. They stare at each other, Merlin implacable, Arthur's eyes pleading. It's obvious that Merlin isn't going to help.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He unsheathes Excalibur and goes forward, kneeling before Uryens and offering him the sword.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arthur, kneeling, bows his head and Uryens steps up to him, his features set. He accepts the sword. Lot watches, a mad hope dancing in his eyes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You are in my hands, to slay or spare. I need battle lords such as you. Swear faith to me and you shall have mercy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Noble knights swear faith to a mere squire?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are right. I'm not yet a knight. (gaining strength) You, Uryens, will knight me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then as knight to knight I can offer you mercy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to himself) What's this, what's this?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Guenevere watches, frightened for Arthur, not daring to breathe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uryens stands towering above the boy. He smiles enigmatically. He lifts Excalibur. Merlin is attempting to push through the crowded ranks to get to Arthur. He's frantic and worried for once.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uryens swiftly lowers the sword on Arthur's neck; with the flat of the blade he gives Arthur the three strokes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arthur looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uryens is deeply moved.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arthur rises and Uryens kneels and kisses his hands. Sir Ector turns away to hide brimming tears. Merlin pushes through finally, out of breath. Uryens embraces Leondegrance while Lot and the other enemy knights kneel in turn and kiss Arthur's hands.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I never saw this...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In the name of God, of Saint Michael and Saint George, I give you the right to bear arms, the power to mete justice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That duty I will solemnly obey as knight and King.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rise, my King. I am your humble knight, and I swear allegiance to the courage in your veins, for so strong it is, it's source must be Uther. I doubt you no more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The castle can be glimpsed through the trees. A clear spring bubbles from the ground, and the sun splashes leaf, bird, squirrel, and bee with golden light, and Arthur and Guenevere too. Guenevere is serious and intent on her work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With water from the spring, she is bathing a large cut on his chest that has been stitched closed. Wounds on his arms, and one on a calf also show evidence of her neat sewing. She's just finishing, and she dabs his chest with a dry cloth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts to get up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arthur shivers at the thought.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arthur smiles at her, enjoying her jealousy, and it irritates her a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She touches his lips with hers, her eyelids fluttering shut. He stares at her young beauty, and draws her into a long, slow kiss. A shrill almost human squeal pierces the air not far away. Arthur pulls away startled, half-rising. Guenevere giggles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She puts her arms around him, drawing him close again, speaking in a half-whisper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They smile at each other, about to kiss. As they come closer:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Owww...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It didn't hurt too much, did it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ye...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: --I'm pretty good at stitchery. I've sewn my father's wounds more than once.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Careful! You'll have to stay still for a few days or you'll tear them open.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I have to leave tomorrow. The forests are thick with rebels, invaders plunder our shores...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: --And damsels in besieged castles are waiting to be rescued?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't know Leondegrance had a daughter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, then, I shall tell you which knights have maiden daughters, so you can avoid their castles.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I think it's better if you just stay here to heal. At least a week.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Quiet, or I'll sew up your mouth too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would you rescue me from a fiery dragon, sir?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's just a furry little rabbit that took the bait and sprung the trap.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll find him served up to you tonight, cooked in a most excellent sauce...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The soft beat of psaltery and the liquid flow of lute. A serving platter bearing roast rabbit in rampant position is carried across the hall. It is laid on the long raised table before Arthur, who presides in the middle. He looks at it suspiciously and blushes, remembering the afternoon; and it looks back at him accusingly with its cherry eye. Guenevere is dancing around her father, lovely, gliding, sensual. She sees Arthur and the rabbit and laughs out-right. He twists off a leg of the rabbit and sinks his teeth into it to hide his embarrassment. Guenevere passes to another partner, smiling at him, radiant. Arthur watches her, his heart breaking. He is in love. Merlin leans close.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only then does he realize that Merlin has understood everything. He is annoyed at being so transparent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A shadow of doubt crosses Arthur's brow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Guenevere approaches, smiling and coquettish. She slaps her hands, and a servant sets down a tray of pastries before Arthur.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She smiles at Arthur's embarrassment and confusion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes a cake and bites into it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Guenevere offers one to Arthur, and he hesitates, looking at it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arthur bites into the cake, and Guenevere looks deep into his eyes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: A king must marry, after all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...of course...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I love her. If she would be my queen, my dreams would be answered.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mischievous) There are maidens as fair, and fairer than Guenevere. If I put my mind to it, I could see them now, many of them, weeping for love of you, watching the hills for you coming from the high towers of their castles. Offering you their every favor. Rich, clever--but if it is to be Guenevere, so be it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who will it be? Put your mind to it, then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Guenevere. And a beloved friend who will betray you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) Guenevere...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're not listening. Your heart is not. Love is deaf as well as blind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They are only for you, for in them I mixed things that heal, but not too quickly; and things that make limbs sleepy, preventing escape, but keep one's mind sharp.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's in them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is an ancient mixture, containing only soft, unborn grains, and flavored with roses. The rest is secret.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Looking at the cake is like looking at the future. Until you have savored its bitterness and its sweetness, its texture and its perfume, what do you really know? And then, of course, it will he too late.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Too late...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ...but for years war kept Arthur from thoughts of marriage."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: War tents have been pitched beneath the majestic trees. Near the banner of the Dragon a doe grazes. Arthur is older, in battle-scarred plate armor, pacing and angry. He is watched by his wounded and bruised knights--Kay, Uryens, Lot, Leondegrance, Caradoc, and some new young faces among the ranks. No one talks. The harsh clank of its battle trappings announces the arrival of a horse. All eyes watch it walk into the camp. A knight is slouched in the saddle. Arthur runs to meet the horse, followed by squires and some of the knights. He eases the rider to the ground, unlaces his helmet. It is Sir Ector, and his hauberk is badly dented. Tears burn in Arthur's eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pushes past the knights and goes to his horse. Kay steps in front of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arthur rises into the saddle and takes a jousting spear from the rack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The squires are silent. Arthur gallops off in the direction Sir Ector came from. His knights are afraid for him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He is the mightiest and fairest of knights.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We fought and won battles, and now one man defeats all my knights? I will go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A king must not engage in single contest. I'll go again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where is Merlin?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: His countenance grim, Arthur gallops along a trail bordering a plowed field when in it a scarecrow moves. It starts to run as stick-wielding farmers pursue it. It is Merlin. Arthur turns off into the field, and at the sight of an armored knight on a war horse, the farmers turn and flee. Merlin stops to catch his breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arthur's hand is clenched tight around Excalibur's hilt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He offers his arm and Merlin hoists himself up behind the King.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (angry) I should have left you to fend for yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I had to weave a little enchantment on the bees so I could get some honey, and I didn't feel up to using any more magic just yet. Anyway, I was in less danger than you'll be in today.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So you were stealing their honey. They should have killed you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come now. So much anger for such a little crime? Are you sure there is nothing else troubling you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know full well there is, and I go to meet it now. Come witness my revenge.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A waterfall cascades into a pool. The spray casts a rainbow. Beneath it is a colorful confusion of flowers and budding trees, a place dreamlike in its beauty. Arthur, with Merlin behind, gallops along the edge of the pool. The trail widens into a field of grass. Arthur reins beside a pile of broken lances and twisted shields. Across the field, pitched upon the trail is a war tent made of diaphanous white silk, a sky blue banner above it. Merlin slides off and Arthur continues. From the tent, a knight with jousting lance rides forward to meet him. His armor is so shiny it is a mirror. His eyes, seen through the open visor, seem to laugh. His speech is foreign, from across the sea. He is Lancelot of the Lake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He crosses himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arthur wheels away, trembling with anger, and gallops to his edge of the field. He sees that Lancelot has already positioned himself and is waiting, lance down. Merlin watches, a spectator, as the two charge at each other. They collide with great force, their spears shattering. Arthur is jolted but stays in the saddle. Lancelot's jousting is impeccable. Arthur draws Excalibur.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pages come forward with new lances for Arthur and Lancelot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arthur grabs the spear from the page's hands, and circles back to work the horse up into an all-out gallop. Lancelot spurs forward to meet him. Arthur is neatly unhorsed. He picks himself up from the ground in a rage, drawing Excalibur. Lancelot on his horse weaves circles around him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arthur charges Lancelot, a raging bull, but cuts and slashes only at the air as Lancelot stays clear of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He dismounts and draws his sword, and they clash. Shield and sword and armor against shield and sword and armor. The swordplay is furious, Arthur attacking, slashing, hacking, Lancelot parrying effortlessly, elegantly defensive. Arthur breaks the onslaught to catch his breath. Lancelot lifts his visor. His eyes are calm, laughing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arthur goes forward attacking with terrible blows upon Lancelot's shield, and Lancelot holds his ground, shield high. And in its mirror-like metal Arthur can see his own reflection, a face distorted by uncontrolled passion. Arthur discards his own shield, grabs Excalibur with both hands, and with a frightening shout that speaks of all his rage, he swings a terrific blow upon the shield, cutting through his own reflection and the metal. And Excalibur snaps in two. A blinding blue-green light explodes from the broken sword. Lancelot, knocked back by the force of the blow, is stunned by the blast and falls to the ground unconscious. Arthur backs away, horrified, half of Excalibur in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merlin approaches, pale, gripped by dread.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arthur picks up the broken blade, utterly undone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merlin stands there, drawn, defeated, his hopes dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Despairing, he flings the two parts of Excalibur into the pool. He kneels at the waters edge, and he cries.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then Arthur sees something that startles him. Beneath the surface, suspended in the blue-green water amid the dancing weeds, he sees Excalibur, intact. It is held by a maiden in flowing gown the color of water, her long hair rippling across her face, obscuring it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arthur dips his hand under the water and grasps the hilt and the moment he does the vision in the blue-green water fades. He rises with Excalibur in hand, and Merlin speaks before Arthur can ask the question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he laughs. Just then Lancelot stirs. Arthur rushes to his side. He loosens his helmet and removes it, uncovering damp curls. The young knight's eyes open, and his laughing charm once more animates his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He embraces Arthur, who is overwhelmed by his childlike directness. The King helps him to his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He thumps his breastplate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lancelot draws his sword, holding it by the blade, a crucifix.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They embrace, and Merlin watches.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good day to you, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Move aside. This is the King's road, and the knights you joined arms against were his very own.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I await the King himself. His knights are in need of training.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am King, and this is Excalibur, sword of kings from the dawn of time. Who are you, and why do you block the way?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am Sir Lancelot of the Lake, from across the sea. I am the best knight in the whole of Christiandom, and I look for the king who is worthy of my sword's service.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: --That is a wild boast. You lack a knight's humility.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not a boast, sir, but a curse. (a cloud passes over his innocent face) Never have I met my match in joust or duel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Move aside!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will not. You must retreat or prove your kingship in the test of arms, under the eyes of God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then may He give me the strength to unhorse you and send you with one blow back across the sea.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hold! I offer you another lance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You joust well, sir. Battle learnt, but tournament fancy. You should ride more forward in the saddle, though.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yield. I have the advantage.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fight me from your horse or on foot, but fight me. Your avoidance mocks me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I sought only not to harm you, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir, your rage has unbalanced you. It seems you would fight to the death against a knight who is not your enemy, for a length of road you can ride around.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So be it, to the death.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is you, sir, who knows not the virtue of humility, as a true king must.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What horror is this? (calling) Merlin!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The sword is broken. Hope is broken...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My pride broke it, my rage broke it... Humiliation and defeat lie in ambush even for a king. (looking at Lancelot) This excellent knight who fought with fairness and grace was meant to win. With Excalibur, I tried to change that verdict.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have lost for all time the ancient sword of my fathers whose power was meant to unite all men, to serve the vanity of a single man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excalibur! Is it true?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Lady of the Lake. Take it. Take it, quickly!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There are infinite worlds within the infinite coils of the Dragon. In one of them, which I have not traveled, the sword was forged. I only know that the King is returned to us through the instrument of his power. The game continues!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks to God, you are alive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sitting up)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: the best knight in the world, bested! This is a great day, for my search is over. I love you, my King.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are still the best knight in Christiandom. You gained a hundred advantages over me. It is I who must love you, for through your courage and patience you taught me a bitter lesson.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then make me your champion and I will always fight in your place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But your life and lands are far from here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I gave up my castles and my lands!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My domain is here, inside this metal skin. And I would pledge to you all that I still own: muscle, bone, blood and the heart that pumps it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And a great heart it is. Sir Lancelot, you will be my champion.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In the name of Jesus Christ and His holy blood, I swear eternal faith to Arthur, King.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Converging from different directions parties of mounted knights enter the war camp. Lancelot among them. They dismount, battle-weary and burning with the excitement of victory. They quench their huge thirst from buckets carried by squires. They rip off hunks of meat from carcasses sizzling on spits over a roaring fire. And they join the throng of knights, where stories of deeds of arms of the day are enthusiastically exchanged. A great number of knights are packed tightly around King Arthur, each man anxious to tell of his victories. One of them has the King's attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arthur sees Lancelot in the throng and moves toward him. Merlin follows Arthur and is pushed and knocked around in the crush of spikes and iron. The only unarmored man in the crowd, he glares at the excited knights irritably.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arthur turns toward Uryens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cheers greet each declaration.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amidst the celebration, a fracas is heard. A knight pushing forward to talk to Arthur has entered a shoving match with those in front of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merlin is brutally jostled. He draws a fistful of powder from his cape and he tosses it into the air above him. He raises his staff into the cloud, cracking it like a whip. The tip of the staff catches fire, and the fire spreads through the powder in the air, stunning all into silence. Merlin shouts and snarls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merlin swings his burning staff into a wide arc. The knights back away, amused at first, then a bit afraid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The knights have fallen back. Merlin stalks past each man, and Arthur too, holding the flaming tip of his staff before each pair of eyes, and staring into them with his gimlet gaze.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The knights have formed a circle. They realize this. Awestruck, they whisper in astonishment, looking up at the sky burning with stars. Merlin brims with pride as he waits for Arthur to recognize his handiwork.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A cheer rises. Arthur strides into the ring of knights.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another bout of cheers goes up, and Arthur stops before Leondegrance, resting his hand on the old knight's shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leondegrance's eyes fill with tears of joy. A roar of cheers. Arthur draws the sword of power.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lancelot is drawn in by the King's enthusiasm. He unsheathes his sword and swoops it low in salute.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In quick succession all knights draw their swords, following Lancelot's example. Merlin struggles to put out the flame on his staff. He finally does it by smothering it with earth. When he looks up again, he sees the knights galloping off in all directions.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...We killed every one of them. Burnt their ship...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lancelot, how did you fare in the North?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We spared the lives of a few, so they could sail home and tell their fellows what fate they met at the hands of King Arthur's knights...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you, Uryens?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Victory!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lot, and you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We drove the invaders into the sea.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You, Gawain, the East?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The East is ours again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The war is over. One land, one King. Peace.
dialogue.name: dialogue
